author: lennysan
full_text:
Things you probably didn't know about  @bhorowitz—the "z" in a16z:

1. He started his career as a rapper

2. He wrote his famous "Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager" as an internal memo out of frustration with his team at Netscape

3. He took his company LoudCloud public https://t.co/LxTNx5tXGX
note_tweet_text:
Things you probably didn't know about  @bhorowitz—the "z" in a16z:

1. He started his career as a rapper

2. He wrote his famous "Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager" as an internal memo out of frustration with his team at Netscape

3. He took his company LoudCloud public with just $2M in ARR (the press called it "The IPO from hell"; they eventually sold it for $1.6B 👌)

4. He coined the terms "Peacetime CEO" and "Wartime CEO"

5. He runs a non-profit called "Paid in Full", which awards pensions to pioneering and overlooked hip-hop artists

6. His core life philosophy is "Life isn't fair," and he thinks this mindset is key to success

Oh, also, he and his firm are investors in: @Facebook, @Airbnb, @Coinbase, @Stripe, @OpenAI, @Uber, @Instagram, @Databricks, @Twitter, @Slack, and essentially every generational company.

In our rare and real-talk conversation, we discuss:
🔸 Why “founder mode” is half right and half dangerously wrong
🔸 The story behind “Good Product Manager/Bad Product Manager”
🔸 Where the biggest AI startup opportunities remain
🔸 Why you need to run toward fear, never away
🔸 The one trait that predicts that a founder will fail as CEO
🔸 Much more

Listen now 👇
• YouTube: https://t.co/wYo8JW3NQ8
• Spotify: https://t.co/NaGauMUlO8
• Apple: https://t.co/xLwXkxJlil

Thank you to our wonderful sponsors for supporting the podcast:
🏆 @DeveloperXM — The developer intelligence platform designed by leading researchers: https://t.co/INhXcJ685b
🏆 @basecamp — The famously straightforward project management system from 37signals: https://t.co/3cBgw6hWf3
🏆 @MiroHQ  — A collaborative visual platform where your best work comes to life: https://t.co/Im5Q57v78w

author: lennysan
full_text:
My favorite wisdom bombs from @bhorowitz:

"The psychological muscle you have to build to be a great leader is to be able to look in the abyss and go, 'Okay, both ways are terrible. That way is slightly better. We're gonna go that way.'"

"A lot of success is about a small thing,
note_tweet_text:
My favorite wisdom bombs from @bhorowitz:

"The psychological muscle you have to build to be a great leader is to be able to look in the abyss and go, 'Okay, both ways are terrible. That way is slightly better. We're gonna go that way.'"

"A lot of success is about a small thing, a small thing that's hard to do that doesn't seem to have a high impact. But it leads to the next small hard-to-do thing and then eventually, you get an outcome."

"The only reason to start a company is because you have an irrational desire to do so. Because it's not worth the money."

"If everyone agrees with the decision, then you didn’t add any value because they would’ve done that without you."

"As CEO, you don't make people great. You find people that make you great."

"No credit will be given for predicting rain. Only credit for building an ark."
cognitive_value: Enables leadership resilience with abyss quote

author: AntonMartyniuk
full_text:
𝗦𝗢𝗟𝗜𝗗 – 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗱𝗺𝗮𝗽 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘀𝗼𝗳𝘁𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗲

Whether you write in C#, Java, TypeScript, or any other language - these rules make your codebase better.

𝗦ingle Responsibility - One job. One reason to change

𝗢pen / https://t.co/O9SFZHGH4m
note_tweet_text:
𝗦𝗢𝗟𝗜𝗗 – 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗱𝗺𝗮𝗽 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝘀𝗼𝗳𝘁𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗲

Whether you write in C#, Java, TypeScript, or any other language - these rules make your codebase better.

𝗦ingle Responsibility - One job. One reason to change

𝗢pen / Closed - Extend ✅, modify ❌

𝗟iskov Substitution - Subclasses must act like their base.

𝗜nterface Segregation - Small, purpose‑built contracts.

𝗗ependency Inversion - Depend on abstractions, not concretes.

📙 𝟭. 𝗦𝗶𝗻𝗴𝗹𝗲 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗶𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 (𝗦𝗥𝗣)

A class, module, or function should do one job and have one reason to change. Logging, database persistence, sending emails — not all three.
Smaller pieces = easier testing & easier maintanance.

📙 𝟮. 𝗢𝗽𝗲𝗻 / 𝗖𝗹𝗼𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 (𝗢𝗖𝗣)

Your code should be open for extension (add new behavior) but closed for modification (core stays intact).
Extract an interface, use decorators or inheritance to plug new features without touching working code.

📙 𝟯. 𝗟𝗶𝘀𝗸𝗼𝘃 𝗦𝘂𝗯𝘀𝘁𝗶𝘁𝘂𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 (𝗟𝗦𝗣)

If Child extends Base, every place that expects Base must be happy with Child.
Penguins can't fly? Then Bird(.)Fly() doesn't belong in class Bird, make a FlyingBird interface instead.

📙 𝟰. 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗳𝗮𝗰𝗲 𝗦𝗲𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 (𝗜𝗦𝗣)

Expose focused interfaces (IReadableStream, IWritableStream) rather than bloated “god” interfaces.
Clients consume only the methods they need — no more, no less.

📙 𝟱. 𝗗𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗻𝗰𝘆 𝗜𝗻𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗽𝗹𝗲 (𝗗𝗜𝗣)

High‑level modules shouldn't import low‑level details. Both depend on abstractions (ILogger, IPaymentGateway).
Switch implementations (console ↔ Seq, mock ↔ real) without touching business logic and dependent classes.

Start simple with Single Responsibility and Dependency Inversion. Add other SOLID principles as the code grows. Your future self (and your teammates) will thank you.

Which principle do you struggle with the most?

—

♻️ Repost to help others learn SOLID principles

➕ Follow me for more

👉 Save 120+ Hours on Setup & Development. Download my .NET Project Blueprint with Production-Grade Code & Architecture and the most modern .NET technical stack:
https://t.co/ztNVCIwgRN
cognitive_value: Enables software design with SOLID principles

author: milan_milanovic
full_text:
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝘀𝗽𝗹𝗶𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗵𝗮𝗹𝗳. 𝗠𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗴 𝗵𝗮𝗹𝗳 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁

Three years into the hiring freeze, the data reveal two distinct markets. Here's what changed.

𝟭. https://t.co/KxxOTgGXHt
note_tweet_text:
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝘁𝗲𝗰𝗵 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁 𝗶𝘀 𝘀𝗽𝗹𝗶𝘁 𝗶𝗻 𝗵𝗮𝗹𝗳. 𝗠𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘄𝗿𝗼𝗻𝗴 𝗵𝗮𝗹𝗳 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗷𝗼𝗯 𝗺𝗮𝗿𝗸𝗲𝘁

Three years into the hiring freeze, the data reveal two distinct markets. Here's what changed.

𝟭. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗔𝗜 𝗲𝘅𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝘂𝗹𝗲

Tech postings crashed 36% below pre-pandemic levels. But dig into the numbers and a pattern emerges.

Machine learning engineers: up 59% since 2020. AI/ML engineers: up 334%. Median salary: $260,000.

Software engineers: down 49%. Web developers: down 60%. Android, Java, iOS developers: down 60%+.

The market picked winners and losers. AI roles survived. Everything else didn't.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗮𝗿𝗴𝗲𝘁: "machine learning engineer," "AI engineer," "data scientist"  
𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗮𝘃𝗼𝗶𝗱: "software engineer," "full-stack developer," anything with "junior"

𝟮. 𝗚𝗲𝗼𝗴𝗿𝗮𝗽𝗵𝘆 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀

The crash wasn't uniform across cities. Boston tech postings down 51%. Austin is down 28%.

The difference? Local economic health. Austin's non-tech jobs grew 11%. Boston fell 8%.

Texas and Southeast metros held up. Seattle, Minneapolis, and San Francisco experienced significant declines alongside their broader economies.

So, remote-first companies bypass geography. San Jose remained a strong hub for AI.

𝟯. 𝗘𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗶𝗻𝗳𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗵𝗶𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗱

42% of postings now require 5+ years of experience, up from 37% in 2022. This shift started after ChatGPT launched.

Entry-level roles shrank to 18% of the market. Mid-tier positions ($ 100,000-$200,000) were the first to be eliminated.

The squeeze happened from both ends. Junior roles disappeared, and senior requirements inflated.

What you can do: Count internships and side projects as experience. Apply at a 70% match rate.

𝟰. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗽𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗲 𝘀𝗮𝗳𝗲𝘁𝘆 𝗻𝗲𝘁

SAP consultants and Salesforce developers continued to hire. These roles help businesses adopt technology instead of building it.

Data center technicians also surged - AI infrastructure requires skilled personnel.

𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆: Target "consultant," "implementation," "enterprise" titles at B2B companies. Avoid consumer apps.

𝟱. 𝗩𝗼𝗹𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝘀𝘄𝗲𝗿

Fewer jobs mean more applications needed. The math is simple, but most engineers won't do it.

Set quota: 15 targeted applications per week. Use the same resume. Customize only the cover letter's first line.

In the end, employment in tech remains up 19% from 2019, despite the hiring freeze. Current workers are fine. Job seekers are screwed.

This gap won't last. Either hiring rebounds or employment drops to match posting levels.

Image: indeed
cognitive_value: Enables job market insight with hiring analysis

author: rohanpaul_ai
full_text:
Another great @GoogleDeepMind paper.

Shows how to speed up LLM agents while cutting cost and keeping answers unchanged.

30% lower total cost and 60% less wasted cost at comparable acceleration.

Agents plan step by step, so each call waits for the previous one, which drags https://t.co/uxyYK3fylW
note_tweet_text:
Another great @GoogleDeepMind paper.

Shows how to speed up LLM agents while cutting cost and keeping answers unchanged.

30% lower total cost and 60% less wasted cost at comparable acceleration.

Agents plan step by step, so each call waits for the previous one, which drags latency.

Speculative planning fixes that by having a cheap draft agent guess next steps while a stronger agent checks them in parallel.

Fixed guess lengths backfire, small guesses barely help, big guesses waste tokens when a check disagrees.

Dynamic Speculative Planning learns how far to guess, then stops early to avoid wasted calls.

A tiny online predictor learns how many steps will be right using reinforcement learning.

1 knob lets teams bias for speed or cost, either by skewing training or adding a small offset.

If a guess is wrong, extra threads stop and execution resumes from the verified step.

Across OpenAGI and TravelPlanner, the dynamic policy matches the fastest fixed policy while spending fewer tokens 

The result is clear, faster responses, lower bills, and 0 loss in task quality.
cognitive_value: Enables agent optimization with cost reduction

author: justinskycak
full_text:
Everyone knows that the easiest way to become insanely skilled is to skill-stack. You know what skills pair really well with each other and basically everything else? Math and coding.

If you’ve got serious math chops, coding chops, and deep domain expertise in another
note_tweet_text:
Everyone knows that the easiest way to become insanely skilled is to skill-stack. You know what skills pair really well with each other and basically everything else? Math and coding.

If you’ve got serious math chops, coding chops, and deep domain expertise in another discipline, then you’re compounding three orders of magnitude. Be one-in-a-hundred on each and now you’re one in a million overall. Be one-in-a-thousand in each and now you’re one in a billion overall.

Pursue a domain you love, but simultaneously get so insanely technically skilled at math and coding that you can apply them to your domain of interest in an innovative way. Deep domain expertise plus alien-level technical skills equals lots of interesting and rewarding work to do.
cognitive_value: Enables skill stacking with math coding synergy

author: e_opore
full_text:
Caching (Redis, Memcached)

What is Caching?

Caching is the process of storing frequently accessed data in a temporary storage (cache) so future requests can be served faster. Instead of querying the database every time, the system retrieves data from the cache, reducing https://t.co/3UPIlKSasp
note_tweet_text:
Caching (Redis, Memcached)

What is Caching?

Caching is the process of storing frequently accessed data in a temporary storage (cache) so future requests can be served faster. Instead of querying the database every time, the system retrieves data from the cache, reducing response time and server load.

Why Caching is Important

→ Improves application performance.
→ Reduces load on the database.
→ Enhances scalability and user experience.
→ Useful in real-time applications where speed is critical.

Redis

Redis (Remote Dictionary Server) is an open-source, in-memory data store often used as a cache, database, and message broker.
→ Stores data in key-value pairs.
→ Supports complex data structures like lists, sets, and hashes.
→ Provides persistence options (data can be saved to disk).
→ Commonly used in session storage, leaderboards, and pub/sub systems.

Advantages of Redis

→ Very fast (in-memory).
→ Rich data types and features.
→ Persistence support (RDB, AOF).
→ Suitable for real-time analytics.

Memcached

Memcached is a high-performance, in-memory caching system designed for simplicity and speed.
→ Stores data in key-value pairs.
→ Focuses only on caching (no persistence, fewer data structures).
→ Commonly used for caching database queries, HTML fragments, or session data.

Advantages of Memcached

→ Simple and lightweight.
→ Extremely fast read/write operations.
→ Scales horizontally across multiple servers.

Redis vs Memcached

→ Redis: Feature-rich, supports persistence and advanced data types.
→ Memcached: Lightweight, purely focused on caching.
→ Redis: Best for applications needing caching + extra functionality.
→ Memcached: Best for simple caching with minimal overhead.

Real-World Examples

→ Redis: Storing user sessions in large-scale apps like Twitter.
→ Memcached: Caching product details on e-commerce sites for faster page loads.

Download The Backend Ebook ( it covers everything above and more)
https://t.co/QdeNEmpNfI
cognitive_value: Enables caching understanding with Redis explanation

author: realmadhuguru
full_text:
Same pattern is emerging for AI PMs. AI product building is a far less mature discipline than AI research.

To build an AI native product, a PM needs mastery of the following
- vision, opinionated UX design
- model intuition to extract max value
- ability to go from pixels ->
note_tweet_text:
Same pattern is emerging for AI PMs. AI product building is a far less mature discipline than AI research.

To build an AI native product, a PM needs mastery of the following
- vision, opinionated UX design
- model intuition to extract max value
- ability to go from pixels -> evals -> hill climb
- understanding of agentic flows - tools, context, safety guardrails
- deep user understanding - lot more than previously because of the nature of agents

Unlike traditional software, LLMs offer infinite use cases with infinite failure modes. It takes skill to craft products that strike the balance between exposing LLM versatility while building a focused product with high quality.

I estimate < 75 PMs globally have this depth. The evidence is the number of truly AI-native products today. And my scar tissue from hiring.

It is a rare, but learnable skillset. Only way is to build, build, build.
cognitive_value: Enables AI PM skills with mastery requirements
